stream_context.summary: Kaze coded and tuned two new enemies (Thimble/“Symbol” shy-guys and a Bert-the-Bashful egg) for the craft-themed Course 14 while live-debugging a tricky texture-scroll bug, then reviewed Biobak’s large visual/performance rework of Course 1 and discussed broader game structure, music, and release plans.

development_findings.summary: Implemented “Symbol Guys” (thimble shy-guys): chase Mario, receive a bully-style kick knock-back, later add a dive attack; decided they are unsquishable due to metal body and will award a coin only after falling.
Solved a texture-scroll bug on Symbol Guy head-shine; root cause was a shadowed variable that GCC optimised away. Fix: renamed variable to avoid shadowing.
development_findings.quote: I was in bizarro world… then I saw the variable was shadowed, GCC threw it out. Renamed it and the shine finally moved.

development_findings.summary: Chose second Course 14 enemy: a large painted-egg ‘Bert the Bashful’. Behaviour: continuously hop toward Mario; contact bounces Mario (no damage) making pits lethal. Visual tweaks: fuzzy pom-pom nose, specular-like shine, cardboard feet.

Course 1 rework (Biobak): 220 fewer triangles, 7 fewer materials, new skybox, windmill, foliage, and brick walls; tree density reduced to cut overdraw. Performance on real N64 unchanged (~60 fps) with more headroom after further sorting.
development_findings.quote: Considering it is the same performance and there’s still optimisation left, this rework will be better overall.

development_findings.summary: Overworld design pivot: entire Yoshi’s Island will be a seamless hub offering a 360° beach view; players unlock deeper island areas as they gain stars.
development_findings.quote: It is super important that the overworld shows the entirety of Yoshi's Island… as you get more stars, you just go deeper into the island.

development_findings.summary: Game scope clarified: ~30 levels (15 main courses); ~135 main stars plus 45 ‘Yoshi Stars’—optional challenges with 11 rule sets (e.g. four stars limit A-presses).
Upcoming Patreon demo: Kaze requested fresh screenshots to announce imminent release.
Technical practice: keeps all behaviours for one actor in a single inc.c to reduce cache misses; compiles with GCC in WSL; fast64 used for level exporting.

context_findings.summary: Kaze moved from Germany to Canada in 2021 and is relieved to escape German bureaucracy.
context_findings.quote: I'm so glad I don't live in Germany anymore— all the bureaucracy bullshit there ruined my quality of life.

context_findings.summary: His day job is C++ programming; employer hired him partly because of his ROM-hacking reputation.
context_findings.quote: Yeah, they actually hired me because of this.

context_findings.summary: Limited stream time due to full-time job and family (Thanksgiving trip, plays Minecraft with wife Zeina).
Philosophy on content: plans to create broader-appeal ‘Mario 64 facts’ videos to ‘get famous’, contrasting with more scientific channels.
context_findings.quote: I’d be like the magazine reporting on the PhD thesis, but a good one.

context_findings.summary: Skeptical of large language models; recent recruiter call convinced him LLMs are ‘just garbage’.
Considering selling a standalone OST cartridge and will consult a lawyer before release for legal safety with Nintendo IP.

biobak.summary: Delivered major Course 1 rework, cutting geometry/materials and adding new art assets; will supply screenshots and fix texture formats for Kaze to import.
biobak.quote: Quick facts—220 fewer tris, 7 fewer materials… all new backgrounds.

biobak.summary: Provided gameplay ideas: knock-back mechanic for Symbol Guys, environmental tweaks (windmill, trees).

badub.summary: Composed first draft of Course 14 music; Kaze likes quality but feels it evokes ‘beach at sunset’ rather than ‘adventure’ and lacks a hummable melody.
badub.quote: It’s beautiful, but for me it doesn’t fit the vibe—feels more like a beach at sunset.

key_stories.title: The Disappearing Shine
key_stories.summary: While adding a reflective highlight to the Symbol Guy’s helmet, Kaze spent significant time debugging why the texture wouldn’t scroll. After stepping through MIPS assembly and even asking ChatGPT, he discovered GCC had optimised away the offset variable because it was shadowed.
key_stories.challenge: Shine scroll refused to animate, even with random offsets.
key_stories.process: Tested in multiple emulators, inspected display lists, opened the debugger, reviewed assembly, consulted ChatGPT.
key_stories.outcome: Renamed the shadowed variable; effect finally worked, illustrating deep-level problem-solving.
key_stories.key_quote: I was in bizarro world… then I saw the variable was shadowed. Rename it and boom—the shine moves.

key_stories.title: Course 1 Makeover
key_stories.summary: Biobak rebuilt Course 1, dramatically reducing draw calls and beautifying the environment. Kaze live-tested the update on real hardware, confirming equal frame-rate with room for further gains.
key_stories.challenge: Original Course 1 suffered overdraw and dated visuals.
key_stories.process: Biobak trimmed 220 triangles, merged 7 materials, retextured foliage and sky, removed trees causing overdraw.
key_stories.outcome: Visual upgrade with no performance loss; slated for Patreon demo.
key_stories.key_quote: Considering it is the same performance and there’s still optimisation left, this rework will be better overall.

key_stories.title: Reimagining the Overworld
key_stories.summary: Kaze had a ‘revelation’ that the entire overworld should depict all of Yoshi’s Island with a full 360° beach vista, letting players delve deeper as they collect stars.
key_stories.challenge: Wanted the hub to feel cohesive and exploratory, not just a level select.
key_stories.process: Brainstormed live, aligning island geography with star progression.
key_stories.outcome: Design pivot will shape world layout and narrative framing.
key_stories.key_quote: It is super important that the overworld is the entirety of Yoshi's Island… you get a 360° view and keep going deeper.
